titleText.ttltext: Efficacy of the canine lyme @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in North America: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Population Medicine, University of Guelph

paras: Lyme disease is endemic to some parts of North America, and is an emerging disease in others. Although tick preventives are available, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is an increasingly common though controversial method used in the prevention of canine Lyme infection; reported efficacies of canine Lyme @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are highly variable, ranging from 50% to 100%. The objective of our research was as follows: to determine the efficacy of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for Borrelia burgdorferi in North American dogs by comparing @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end dogs to those not receiving the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. We used a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to address this objective. Monovalent and multivalent @hit_startvaccines@hit_end were considered eligible interventions. Our main outcome of interest was the reduction of clinical illness following exposure to B. burgdorferi. Outcome data were extracted as a binary outcome for the following clinical signs (assessed separately): lameness, anorexia, pyrexia, depression, lymphadenopa-thy. Experimental and @hit_startanalytical@hit_end observational studies were considered eligible for inclusion. In addition to grey literature searches, the following electronic databases were searched with no language restrictions: @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, Web of Science, CAB Abstracts. The last search was performed on November 29, 2016. Thirteen challenge trials and three observational studies were identified as eligible, and twelve challenge trials contained sufficient data to be included in our @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end could not be performed for observational studies due to an insufficient number of studies. None of the challenge trials assessed lymphadenopathy, but for each of the remaining four clinical signs a separate random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was performed. With the exception of anorexia, all summary odds ratios were less than the null value of 1. Overall, the findings of our @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end suggest that North American Lyme @hit_startvaccines@hit_end reduce the odds of clinical illness in dogs following exposure to B. burgdorferi. However, these results should be interpreted with caution since a number of issues related to small sample size, study quality, and publication bias were identified. No experimental field trials were identified, highlighting a major gap in the literature on this topic. Future studies should focus on larger sample sizes in field conditions.

titleText.ttltext: Reducing the burden of rheumatic heart disease: Prevalence of group a streptococcus EMM clusters in Africa suggests adequate coverage by 30-valent @hit_startvaccine@hit_end

paras: Introduction: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end prevention of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) infections is considered by many to be the most promising long-term approach to the prevention of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). A 30-valent @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, based on 30 of the >220 GAS emm-types encoding the cell surface M-protein, is currently undergoing preclinical trials, Sanderson-Smith subsequently devised a classification system grouping emm-types into 48 emm clusters, suggesting a cross-protection framework, and potentially extending @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage to all or most GAS serotypes. Hypothesis: Considering GAS emm cluster classification, the 30-valent @hit_startvaccine@hit_end currently under development provides poor coverage across Africa, compared with the rest of the world. Methods: Based on methods from the guidelines offered by the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Collaboration, the @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end approach was employed to obtain prevalent emm-types and clusters from published literature to determine the distribution of GAS emm clusters in Africa and worldwide. We conducted a comprehensive search across a number of databases. Applying a priori criteria for inclusion, we selected articles reporting on prevalence of GAS emm-types and emm clusters regardless of region. Emm-types were converted to emm clusters where necessary. Data were extracted onto purpose-designed forms, captured electronically and @hit_startanalysed@hit_end using Stata software. Results: The final dataset included 51,621 isolates, representing 159 different emm-types recovered from 39 countries in seven regions worldwide, (97 studies: Europe, n=35; Asia-Pacific, n=27; Oceania, n=13, North America, n=10; Latin America, n=6; Africa, n=4; Arab states, n=2). @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the worldwide emm clusters revealed that most represented was E4 (18% of n=51,621 isolates) which is included in the putative @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. In Africa, which has amongst the highest RHD burden, the most prominent cluster was E6 (19% of n=860 isolates) which is also included in the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. Emm Clusters not included in the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end were largely absent in isolates from Africa. Conclusion: It is evident that the suggested emm cluster cross-protection framework has potential for implementation in future @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efforts, thus ensuring GAS coverage in Africa.

titleText.ttltext: HLA class I subtypes are associated with immune-related adverse events in patients with melanoma treated with ipilimumab

organizations: Perelman School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania

paras: Background Checkpoint immunotherapies have demonstrated substantial benefit in patients with melanoma. However, there are currently no established biomarkers to predict immune-related adverse events (irAEs). Because genetic variation at the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) locus is associated with increased risk of autoimmune disorders, we evaluated associations between irAEs and HLA subtypes. Methods We utilized clinical and genomic data from 269 chemotherapy and immunotherapy-naïve melanoma patients treated with ipilimumab monotherapy on the Bristol-Meyers-Squibb clinical trial CA184-169 (NCT01515189). DNA samples were genotyped on Affymetrix 6.0 and standard sample- and SNP-level quality control pipelines were conducted; only samples with high levels of European genetic ancestry (i.e. Caucasian) were further @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end. Genotype imputation was completed using the Haplotype Reference Consortium Backbone. We used SNP2HLA to establish estimated allele dosages for each 4-digit HLA allele (n = 172), and subsequently collapsed these calls into one of nine established class I supertypes. We catalogued occurrences of immune-related adverse events by CTCAE grade and affected organ system. Logistic regression was performed to evaluate associations of class I HLA supertype allele dosage with irAE outcomes (grade < 2 vs grade ≥ 2) adjusting for ECOG score, dosage, and number of doses. Results HLA-A24 was significantly associated with hepatitis (Grade > 2), with @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end odds ratio 3.69 [95% CI 1.75 to 7.51, p = 0.0005]. Odds ratio was 3.54 [95% CI 1.51 to 8.31, p = 0.0036] in the BMS dataset (remaining significant after correction for multiple comparisons), and OR 3.85 [95% CI 0.96 to 15.5, p = 0.056] from the consortium data set. The frequency of HLA-A24 in our population was 9.6%. Conclusions Our results demonstrate that a specific HLA subtype, HLA-A24, is associated with checkpoint-inhibitor related hepatitis. HLA-A24 has been explored in its dose-dependent response to hepatitis B and C @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Our results potentially demonstrate unmasking of germline-mediated immune sensitivity by checkpoint inhibitors. This data warrants further study into HLA subtypes as predictive biomarkers for immune-related adverse effects. These findings should be confirmed in additional study populations, potentially with sequence-based HLA typing.

titleText.ttltext: Vitiligo and thyroid disease: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Dermatology, Wan Fang Hospital, Taipei Medical University

paras: Vitiligo is associated with (autoimmune) thyroid disease. However, confounding factors, including type and onset of vitiligo, require elucidation. We conducted a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to identify vitiligo patients with increased risk of (autoimmune) thyroid disease. Studies were identified based on searches in @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library from inception of these databases to August 31st, 2017. Odds ratios (ORs) for the prevalence of (autoimmune) thyroid disease and thyroid antibodies in vitiligo patients were pooled, and subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end was performed. Thirty-seven studies with 78,714 vitiligo patients met the inclusion criteria. The prevalence of thyroid disease (TD) (OR: 3.932; 95% CI: 2.230–6.933), autoimmune TD (OR: 5.879; 95% CI: 2.682–12.885), anti-thyroperoxidase (TPO) antibody (OR: 3.838; 95% CI: 2.968–4.963), and anti-thyroglobulin antibody (OR: 3.513; 95% CI: 2.346–5.260) was significantly higher in vitiligo patients than in controls. Notably, the prevalence of TD and anti-TPO antibody was significantly higher in patients with non-segmental vitiligo, compared to those with segmental vitiligo. In contrast, the prevalence of TD was significantly lower in early-, compared to the late-onset vitiligo group (OR: 0.333; 95% CI: 0.244–0.453). Physicians should be aware of the increased risk of (autoimmune) thyroid disease in vitiligo patients. We recommend routine screening for anti-thyroid antibodies in vitiligo patients.

titleText.ttltext: Therapeutic human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in head and neck cancer: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of current clinical trials

organizations: Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery and Audiology, Rigshospitalet, University of Copenhagen

paras: Objectives: This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end provides an overview of the current clinical trials investigating therapeutic @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for HPV+ head and neck cancer and discusses the future directions of therapeutic @hit_startvaccine@hit_end therapy. Materials and methods: A systematic search was conducted in @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end and clinicaltrials.gov for clinical trials involving therapeutic @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. We included studies initiated between 2000 and 2018 with patients diagnosed with HPV+ head and neck cancer and extracted data concerning type of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end therapy, adverse events, immunogenicity and clinical outcome measures (e.g. tumour response, progression-free survival and overall survival). Results: We identified 11 studies (n = 376 patients) initiated between year 2005 and 2017. Four studies (n = 34) presented preliminary results in patients with incurable, recurrent loco-regional or distant metastatic disease indicating a positive immune response with 74% (n = 25/34 patients) having elevated antibody levels, IFN-γ and/or T-cell response. Five studies presented data on the @hit_startvaccines@hit_end’ safety profile, demonstrating predominantly grade 1 and 2 toxicity. Three studies evaluated the clinical outcome – one study showed no complete or partial response, one study demonstrated stable disease as the best tumour response in 64% (n = 9/14 patients) and one study showed a 33% overall response rate: one patient with a complete response and seven patients with a partial response. Conclusions: Treatment with therapeutic @hit_startvaccines@hit_end is a promising and seemingly safe strategy for patients with HPV+ head and neck cancer. However, there are not enough data to draw any further conclusions and clinical outcome measures and tumour responses to the @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are still missing.

titleText.ttltext: Midwives’ attitudes, beliefs and concerns about childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end: A review of the global literature

organizations: School of Social Science, University of Western Australia

paras: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end hesitancy in industrialised countries is an area of concern. Health professionals play a significant role in parental @hit_startvaccination@hit_end decisions, however, to date the role of midwives has not been widely explored. This review sought to describe the attitudes and communication practices of midwives in developed countries towards childhood @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. @hit_startMedline@hit_end, @hit_startCinahl@hit_end, @hit_startPsychInfo@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end and the grey literature were searched. Inclusion criteria were qualitative and quantitative studies reporting midwives’ beliefs, attitudes and communication practices toward childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. The search returned 366 articles, of which 359 were excluded by abstract. Two additional articles were identified from the grey literature and references, resulting in nine studies from five countries included in the review. Across the studies, the majority of midwives supported @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, although a spectrum of beliefs and concerns emerged. A minority expressed reservations about the scientific justification for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, which focussed on what is not yet known rather than mistrust of current evidence. Most midwives felt that @hit_startvaccines@hit_end were safe; a minority were unsure, or believed they were unsafe. The majority of midwives agreed that childhood @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are necessary. Among those who expressed doubt, a commonly held opinion was that @hit_startvaccine@hit_end preventable diseases such as measles are relatively benign and didn't warrant @hit_startvaccination@hit_end against them. Finally, the midwifery model of care was shown to focus on providing individualised care, with parental choice being placed at a premium. The midwifery model care appears to differ in approach from others, possibly due to a difference in the underpinning philosophies. Research is needed to understand how midwives see @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, and why there appears to be a spectrum of views on the subject. This information will inform the development of resources tailored to the midwifery model of care, supporting midwives in advocating for childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Antimicrobial prophylaxis for adult patients with cancer-related immunosuppression: ASCO and IDSA clinical practice guideline update

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 by American Society of Clinical Oncology.
paras: To provide an updated joint ASCO/Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guideline on antimicrobial prophylaxis for adult patients with immunosuppression associated with cancer and its treatment. Methods ASCO and IDSA convened an update Expert Panel and conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of relevant studies from May 2011 to November 2016. The guideline recommendations were based on the review of evidence by the Expert Panel. Results Six new or updated @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end and six new primary studies were added to the updated @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end. Recommendations Antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis is recommended for patients who are at high risk of infection, including patients who are expected to have profound, protracted neutropenia, which is defined as <100 neutrophils/μL for > 7 days or other risk factors. Herpes simplex virus- seropositive patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation or leukemia induction therapy should receive nucleoside @hit_startanalog@hit_end@hit_start-based@hit_end antiviral prophylaxis, such as acyclovir. Pneumocystis jirovecii prophylaxis is recommended for patients receiving chemotherapy regimens that are associated with a > 3.5% risk for pneumonia as a result of this organism (eg, those with ≥ 20 mg prednisone equivalents daily for ≥ 1 month or on the basis of purine @hit_startanalog@hit_end usage). Treatment with a nucleoside reverse transcription inhibitor (eg, entecavir or tenofovir) is recommended for patients at high risk of hepatitis B virus reactivation. Recommendations for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and avoidance of prolonged contact with environments that have high concentrations of airborne fungal spores are also provided within the updated guideline.

titleText.ttltext: Novel approaches to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development in lower-middle income countries

paras: Purpose: The purpose of this paper is to identify, @hit_startanalyze@hit_end and describe the novel approaches that affect @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development in lower-middle income countries (LMICs). Design/methodology/approach: The @hit_startvaccine@hit_end market in LMICs currently focuses on traditional Expanded Program for @hit_startImmunization vaccines@hit_end instead of new ones. Unlike the successful introduction of those traditional @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, the introduction of new @hit_startvaccines@hit_end appears to be very slow, mainly due to financial issues. This paper @hit_startsystematically reviews@hit_end a set of published papers on @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development and @hit_startanalyzes@hit_end them against a specific region-setting framework. Findings: Public–private partnership alone could not ensure long-term @hit_startvaccine@hit_end sustainability. Several factors that encourage domestic @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development were identified. The findings demonstrate that the regulatory approach of hybrid collaboration and market opportunity strategies can be a major breakthrough for domestic @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development in LMICs. Research limitations/implications: Further research is required to include qualitative and quantitative methods for policy @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, as all of the discussion in this research focused on @hit_startliterature reviews@hit_end. The authors did not discuss how strategic decisions are affected from a political perspective and this needs to be specified in future research. Think tanks, considerably and fundamentally, affect policy ideas and decisions. However, important breakthroughs continue to be made at the same time. Social implications: The development of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in LMICs is expected to be a mechanism to overcome the inadequate access to @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in those countries, as solving this problem requires tackling issues from both the supply and demand sides. Originality/value: This is a @hit_startliterature review@hit_end that creates recommendation and approaches for domestic @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development in LMICs. This review aims to encourage LMICs to produce their own @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for sustainability of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end access through @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development lifecycle, instead of expecting donor that provides funding and @hit_startvaccines@hit_end (@hit_startvaccine@hit_end access) in certain period of time. Donor is not always the solution for the problem, since @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development requires finance to function infrastructure. There are many efforts in revoking this, including World Health Organization through several reports; however, this effort still has many doubts. Therefore, the article would like to try to see this as a viable solution from the policy perspectives, with several examples to make recommendations more practical.
